page.title: 16SUTTON PASSEYS VILLAGE
page.content: Before the Conquest, Sutton (South Town) consisted of 2 manors held by Saxons (Aluric & Brun) and rated for {Danegeld}at 12 Bovates (about 180 acres). Sutton and Wollaton were passed to the{Peverell}family at the Conquest but already described as 'waste'. By the early 13th C. the land had passed to the{Passeys}family and had become known as{Sutton Passeys.} In 1339 the manor was transferred to { {William de Willoughby,}Lord of the manor of Wollaton. At the time of his death in 1363 he owned a dwelling, a dovecote, 40 acres of land, 4 acres of meadow and 6 shillings in rent. The moors of Sutton, Wollaton and Lenton were eventually enclosed to form {Wollaton Park}- the arable fields became Lenton & Radford. The remains of the manor are now beneath the Ring Road roundabout. {Ellen Pudney}
